text: hi this is Seema and I am back with a
new lesson on idioms expressing emotions
well emotions are something that we go
through every day whether we are happy
or sad or just plain angry so it is very
important that we know how to express
our emotions in the right way and
therefore I came up with some very
interesting idioms to make sure you do
it the right way the first idiom talks
about being very very angry well have
you ever been in a position where you
are so angry that you want to kill
someone well there's an expression or an
idiom that talks about being angry so
when you are angry you can say that I
blew my top so the idiom is to blow one
stop so I can say that I blew my top
when the traffic police got me even
though I did not run a signal another
way of expressing anger is to say that
you threw a fit you could say my father
threw a fit when I dropped his cellphone
which was very expensive so these are
the expressions or idioms which talk
about being very angry and our next
idiom is to get cold feet well what
expression or what emotion are we
talking about we're talking about fear
or being very scared so when I say that
I get cold feet I'm talking about being
very scared or maybe being very anxious
so I could say that my friend got cold
feet just minutes before she had to do
her parachute jump or I get cold feet
you know a couple of minutes before
giving my
test my math test you know we all get
cold feet when we give our math test
don't we so that's what you know being
scared or getting cold feet is all about
and our next expression talks about
being very frustrated so when I'm
talking about being very frustrated I am
actually telling myself or someone else
that I am sick and tired of a particular
thing so I could say that I am sick and
tired of doing a nine-to-five job I am
sick and tired of taking care of all the
mess around the house I'm talking about
being very very frustrated and our next
expression relates to remembering a
thing so when you want to remember
something you say that something rings a
bell so I could say that
this story that I've heard rings a bell
about what happened the other day so it
relates or brings to memory a certain
event so ringing a bell is nothing but
remembering a thing from something else
so I could say that the movie I watched
rang a bell about an incident that
occurred last evening that's what
remembering or ringing a bell is all
about our next expression is hate
someone's guts well this is quite
self-explanatory because we talk about
hate or really disliking someone a lot
so when I'm talking about an intense
dislike or really hating something a lot
I would say that I hate someone's guts a
lot of you hate your your bosses guts a
lot of you hate your parents gods when
they really you know shout at you don't
you so
hating someone's guts is all about not
liking something or not liking a
particular person now let's have a look
at another five idioms expressing
emotions our next idiom is giving
someone the cold shoulder well what does
that literally mean giving the cold
shoulder is expressing rejection or when
you ignore someone so if you want to
ignore or if you want to really reject
someone or maybe avoid someone you call
that giving them the cold shoulder so I
could say something that something like
my friend always gave her her colleagues
the cold shoulder because she was really
proud so when you give someone the cold
shoulder you kind of think that you are
you know a little bit up there you're a
little better than everyone else
so that's why you ignore reject or try
to avoid people who you think are not as
good as you are and our next expression
is being down in the dumps well what is
this expression talk about the emotion
that we are talking about is being sad
or when you have a lot of grief or to
put it very plainly we're talking about
someone who is being very depressed so I
could say something that people are
always down in the dumps when there is a
recession people are always down in the
dumps when they have been unemployed for
a very long period of time so being down
in the dumps is nothing but being very
sad wallowing in grief and being quite
depressed and we have another idiom
which is being worried sick well as the
expression itself talks about the word
worry we're talking about the emotion of
being very worried
or being very anxious or almost being
panic-stricken
so when I say I am worried sick about my
children or my mother was worth sick
when I did not come up until 2:00 in the
morning so we're talking about being
very anxious being very worried being
almost panic-stricken and our next
expression is to be bored to death well
as the world again talks about the
emotion that is being expressed here is
of absolute boredom you're just tired
you're sick of it okay so when I say I'm
bored to death of my of the story being
told to me or I am bored to death of
taking this test or I'm bored to death
of being in this class for over two
hours so you're talking about something
that does not interest you at all you
are really really bored okay
and our last expression which will show
the best emotion we all like to feel and
that's being very very happy so when you
are very happy the expression that you
are going to talk about is in seventh
heaven so you could say that when I went
to the picnic or the park I was in
seventh heaven when I went for my first
drive in my new car I was in seventh
heaven when I when the kids went out to
the zoo they were in seventh heaven so
you talked about being very happy very
elated and very very you know in a very
good place yeah so that brings me to the
end of this lesson on idioms expressing
emotions well I'll be back with some new
lessons until then it's me saying
goodbye
